concept.title: Lubrication Guidelines for Typewriters
concept.shortdesc: Proper lubrication is essential for maintaining the smooth operation and longevity of typewriter components.

conbody.p: Portable typewriters do not need regular lubrication, as they are protected by their casing. However, metal-on-metal components can develop friction, wrequiring occasional lubrication.
Only use light weight oils. Acceptable oils include sewing machine oils, gun oils, and specialized typewriter lubricants.
conbody.note: Never use heavy oils, like motor oils and other household lubricants. Heavy oils will cause gears and links to gum up over time.
Never oil rubber components, such as the platen, feeder, or paper bail rollers. Oil will degrade the rubber and transfer oil onto the ink ribbon and paper.
Avoid oiling the segment, vibrator mechanics, and line spacing mechanics. These components are susceptible to attracting dust and debris.
conbody.p: Identify metal-on-metal connections, gears, and pivot points that are hesitant in movement or completely stiff. Common areas requiring lubrication include the carriage rails and internal pivot points, levers, and gears.
Using a precision applicator, such as a small pipet or medicine dropper, apply one to two drops of oil where needed, immediately wiping away the excess with a rag or cotton swab.
conbody.note: It is important not to excessively oil a typewriter. Even light weight lubricants will attract debris over time, causing more damage over time. Use minimal oil, wiping away excess as you go.
